content.title: Williams Syndrome (Williams-Beuren Syndrome)
content.description: A genetic disorder caused by deletion on chromosome 7 characterized by distinctive facial features, intellectual disability, supravalvular aortic stenosis, and diffuse arteriopathy.
content.definition: Williams syndrome is a microdeletion syndrome (7q11.23) affecting elastin gene (ELN), causing arterial stenoses throughout the body. The most common and clinically significant vascular manifestation is supravalvular aortic stenosis, but any artery can be affected including renal, pulmonary, and coronary arteries.

surgical_considerations: SVAS repair may require patch aortoplasty
Sudden cardiac death risk from coronary stenosis
Renal artery stenosis may require revascularization

cross_domain_references.description: Williams syndrome is a microdeletion syndrome

learning_objectives: Identify genetic basis of Williams syndrome
Understand multisystem nature of the syndrome
clinical_pearls: SVAS is the classic finding but any artery can be affected
Sudden death risk from coronary stenosis - requires screening
Elastin deficiency affects arterial wall development
